text:
Hey, I have a question about choosing the right site structure for a new blog.

I see some companies having it the "normal" way:  <http://example.com/blog|example.com/blog>, while others (like Backlinko) prefer to do it without /blog and just write massive guides in one scroll: <https://backlinko.com/content-marketing-this-year>

What are your thoughts on this? Is any of them better/worse? Any resources where I could get myself educated about this + some technical SEO?

elements.text:
Hey, I have a question about choosing the right site structure for a new blog.

I see some companies having it the "normal" way:
example.com/blog
, while others (like Backlinko) prefer to do it without /blog and just write massive guides in one scroll:
What are your thoughts on this? Is any of them better/worse? Any resources where I could get myself educated about this + some technical SEO?

text:
It’s a matter of preference. I personally prefer a neat information architecture, which means information is properly ordered. Blog articles go into `/blog/`, our Academy articles go into `/academy/` and so on. You could argue that it’s also easier to track performance in Analytics if your content is better organized but you could use something like virtual pageviews to achieve that if I were to go for a flat URL structure.

If you expect to publish a lot of content, I’d neatly categorize it. If it’s just 10-20 pages in total on a site, a flat URL structure (without subfolders) is fine

elements.text: It’s a matter of preference. I personally prefer a neat information architecture, which means information is properly ordered. Blog articles go into
/blog/
, our Academy articles go into
/academy/

and so on. You could argue that it’s also easier to track performance in Analytics if your content is better organized but you could use something like virtual pageviews to achieve that if I were to go for a flat URL structure.

If you expect to publish a lot of content, I’d neatly categorize it. If it’s just 10-20 pages in total on a site, a flat URL structure (without subfolders) is fine

text: this doesn’t really touch on Technical SEO, it’s more of a preference

elements.text: this doesn’t really touch on Technical SEO, it’s more of a preference

text: something to consider is the URL’s length. So having a flat URL structure makes for shorter URLs, but when you have a lot of content it comes at a cost — a messy information architecture.

elements.text: something to consider is the URL’s length. So having a flat URL structure makes for shorter URLs, but when you have a lot of content it comes at a cost — a messy information architecture.

text: keep the future in mind too, changing URL structure is easy but the migration that follows is a PITA. Avoid migrations where you can

elements.text: keep the future in mind too, changing URL structure is easy but the migration that follows is a PITA. Avoid migrations where you can

text:
We use <http://dispatch.m.io|dispatch.m.io> instead of <http://m.io/blog|m.io/blog> - I can honestly say it has made no difference in this case. We rank #1 for our most important posts and high for everything else.

There's a lot of theory out there about structure but I'd only listen to people who have changed/experimented for real-world insights.

elements.text: We use
dispatch.m.io
instead of
m.io/blog

- I can honestly say it has made no difference in this case. We rank #1 for our most important posts and high for everything else.

There's a lot of theory out there about structure but I'd only listen to people who have changed/experimented for real-world insights.

text:
To add to what Steven said (which was excellent):

It also depends a lot on the structure of your site/how much content you have and how you want to spread it out.

Backlinko is mostly a blog, so Brian can get away with not using a folder for the blog, but if you have landing pages, blog, academy, etc. it would get messy quickly and it’s definitely better to use a folder (/blog/, etc.)

elements.text:
To add to what Steven said (which was excellent):

It also depends a lot on the structure of your site/how much content you have and how you want to spread it out.

Backlinko is mostly a blog, so Brian can get away with not using a folder for the blog, but if you have landing pages, blog, academy, etc. it would get messy quickly and it’s definitely better to use a folder (/blog/, etc.)

text: from an SEO perspective shorter URLs work better, but making the architecture clearer through the strategic use of folders also has benefits from the point of SEO

elements.text: from an SEO perspective shorter URLs work better, but making the architecture clearer through the strategic use of folders also has benefits from the point of SEO

text: finally, it’s also user friendly. Having your blog under a folder (/blog/) makes is miles easier to track it in Google Analytics without having to be an analytics magician

elements.text: finally, it’s also user friendly. Having your blog under a folder (/blog/) makes is miles easier to track it in Google Analytics without having to be an analytics magician

text: Hello! Not all of our members are guys. In an effort to be more conscious of the language we use to address each other, why not try “Hey, folks,” or “Hey everyone” instead?

to add to the Backlinko stuff: Brian has been moving content and restructuring his site’s architecture constantly, based on new insights and results. It’s never done, and I’m sure he too regrets some of the decisions he’s made. His IA is very work-in-progress

text: For us, it is also really important for reporting on our site traffic. Our /blog/ traffic numbers are pretty different than our /products/ traffic numbers, so having those in the url structure makes it easy to filter by section of the website in Google Analytics.

elements.text: For us, it is also really important for reporting on our site traffic. Our /blog/ traffic numbers are pretty different than our /products/ traffic numbers, so having those in the url structure makes it easy to filter by section of the website in Google Analytics.

text: Hey <@UUJBPA9K5>! I don't have a matrix to share but more of a process - we also have this problem and while we don't want to discourage requests we also want them to be prioritized, like you said. Currently we have the requests go to sales enablement, then to product marketing, who decides if it is a priority against the needs of the business, then back down to content to produce.

text: <@U01ANAZTZTK> a hack you can use to get around that – many blogs have “Blog” in the page title or some other unique string. Use “Page Title” as your filter, and filter for e.g. “Blog”, instead of using the URL. that lets you use whatever URLs you want.

text:
Thanks everybody. One of the major problems is that sources don’t seem to 100% agree on what a content audit actually entails. Some say to catalog every single piece of content that has ever been created (whether you’re doing your own content or something for a client), including social media posts and all markers of engagement/performance. This seems ridiculously excessive to me, as well as unattainable.

What I have in mind for a client I’m working with right now is to get a handle on the entire extent of their blog content, and perhaps their video content on YouTube, too. Those are the two main channels for them.

I know they have a diverse range of blog articles, but it’s also become apparent that they tend to repeat themselves on certain topics. Trying to help them really narrow down and focus.
